comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content: The turkeys just thought they were off for a merry jaunt!?  ;)

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: This is a classic and a great image of the time that was in it.  The turkeys were stopped the same way they are today with string on wings and feet as morrisoxfordV says, or else each in tied sacks.  The one thing for sure is they were all fresh!  Apropos your tags - I see lots of 'yokes' if you know what I mean but no yokes.  Have you see something I've missed?  I know I'm getting to be like a bat but I can see what matters - usually!

comment.author: 59941010@N06
comment._content: Excellent shot !

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] You've caught me out again! Wasn't entirely sure about yoke, but hadn't time to check (and playing Devil's Advocate with myself, decided that yoke has endless meanings in Hiberno-English). Thought yoke was the sticky outy (technical term) bit of the cart either side of the horse or donkey. Just googled and yoke is apparently more the double collar of oxen, etc. So, what are the sticky outy bits called?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: Shafts, I believe!?

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Shawlies should be shawls I believe, the Waterford shawl was still worn by some old ladies at least up until the early 1960's.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] Oh sorry, should have tagged with shawls as well, for the garment itself. Shawlies is the word for the woman wearing a shawl. It's quite regional but I thought it might help people find this photo...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Thought about it afterwards and realised it was probably regional, never heard it before myself, its sad but I'm old enough to remember them being worn:)

comment.author: 22575440@N07
comment._content: very sad that it is December and the boy has no shoes, no coat and the ground looks wet too.

comment.author: 47945488@N06
comment._content: thank you for sharing this photo, it is quite revealing.

comment.author: 35277876@N05
comment._content: Good photo, especially viewed original size. There is quite a difference between the lady with the scarf and the boy with no shoes. I wonder what the man at the bottom left is saying / shouting? A good atmospheric shot portraying the affluance / poverty of the time.

comment.author: 24474458@N08
comment._content: I agree with all the comments above except John Edward Ewing...contented...no.... most were very poor...and has not the choice of being 'contented'...the example being the poor little lad with no shoes on his feet..in such cold weather in December....and no one cared it seemed..... Thank God for the 'welfare state ' now...at least they would be given shoes and warm clothes.....
